tc_extremes module¶

class tc_extremes.TCExtremes¶

Bases: object

Class that examines storm data from HURDAT2 and IBTrACS using extreme value theory.

ocean_basin¶

The ocean basin for which storm data is fetched. Possible values are: - ‘north_atlantic’ - ‘east_pacific’ - ‘both’ - ‘west_pacific’ - ‘north_indian’ - ‘south_indian’ - ‘australia’ - ‘south_pacific’ - ‘south_atlantic’ - ‘all’

Defaults to None until set by the fetch method.

Type:

str

basin_dataset¶

The dataset containing storm track information for the specified basin. Initialized by the fetch method.

Type:

tropycal.tracks.TrackDataset

storm_data¶

The pandas DataFrame containing fetched storm data. Populated by the fetch method.

Type:

pd.DataFrame

ev_params_¶

The parameters of the fitted Generalized Extreme Value (GEV) distribution. Set by the fit method. - If method is ‘all’, ev_params_ is a tuple (shape, loc, scale). - If method is ‘season’, ev_params_ is a dictionary mapping each season to a tuple (shape, loc, scale).

Type:

tuple or dict

evaluate(storm_data=None, variable='vmax', ev_params=None)¶

Evaluates the fit of the GEV distribution to the real data by comparing GEV probabilities to the empirical data distribution.

Parameters:

  • storm_data (pd.DataFrame, optional) – The storm data to evaluate. Defaults to the class attribute storm_data.

  • variable (str, optional) – The variable to evaluate. Defaults to ‘vmax’.

  • ev_params – The GEV parameters to use for scoring. - If array-like, should be an array like of (shape, loc, scale). - If a dict, should be {season: (shape, loc, scale)}.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the empirical and GEV probabilities for comparison.

Return type:

dict

fetch(start_year=None, end_year=None, ocean_basin='north_atlantic')¶

Fetches storm data for the specified timeframe and location.

Parameters:

  • start_year (int, optional) – The starting year (inclusive). Defaults to None, fetching all available storms.

  • end_year (int, optional) – The ending year (inclusive). Defaults to None, fetching all available storms.

  • ocean_basin (str, optional) – The ocean basin to fetch data for. Possible values are: - ‘north_atlantic’ - ‘east_pacific’ - ‘both’ - ‘west_pacific’ - ‘north_indian’ - ‘south_indian’ - ‘australia’ - ‘south_pacific’ - ‘south_atlantic’ - ‘all’ Defaults to ‘north_atlantic’.

Returns:

Pandas DataFrame containing storm data for the specified time and location.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

Raises:

ValueError – If the specified ocean_basin is not supported.

fit(storm_data=None, variable='vmax', fit_window=0)¶

Fits storm_data to the Generalized Extreme Value (GEV) distribution.

Parameters:

  • storm_data (pd.DataFrame, optional) – A pandas DataFrame containing the storm data to fit. Defaults to None, which uses the fetched data stored in the class attribute storm_data.

  • variable (str, optional) –

    The variable in the DataFrame to fit to. Possible values are:

    • ’vmax’: maximum wind speeds.

    • ’mslp’: minimum central pressure.

      Fitting to mslp requires flipping the data to accurately model the behavior of the tail.

    Defaults to ‘vmax’.

  • fit_window (int, optional) – How many years/seasons of data to use when fitting. Defaults to 0, fit to the entire dataset.

Returns:

tuple[float, float, float]]:

  • If fit_window is 0, returns a tuple (shape, loc, scale).

  • If fit_window is >0, returns a dictionary mapping each season window to a tuple (shape, loc, scale).

Return type:

tuple[float, float, float] or dict[tuple[int,int]

Raises:

ValueError – If variable is not supported or fit_window is negative or not an int.

plot_agg(storm_data=None, variable='vmax', window=10, min_periods=None, show_plot=True, plot_path='')¶

Plots the moving average of the annual maximum or minimum of the specified variable over time.

Parameters:

  • storm_data (pd.DataFrame, optional) – The storm data to plot. Defaults to the class attribute storm_data.

  • variable (str) – The variable to plot. Defaults to ‘vmax’.

  • window (int) – Number of years to consider for moving average. Defaults to 10.

  • min_periods (int) – Minimum number of years required to have valid values, result is otherwise np.nan. Defaults to None, the size of the window.

  • show_plot (bool) – Whether to display the plot(s). Defaults to True.

  • plot_path (str) – Path to save the plot(s). If plotting multiple seasons, provide a directory path. Defaults to ‘’ (does not save).

Returns:

The matplotlib Axes object with the plot.

Return type:

Axes

Raises:

ValueError – If variable is not supported.

plot_dist(storm_data=None, variable='vmax', window=5, show_plot=True, plot_path='')¶

Plots the kernel density of the data over specified time periods.

Parameters:

  • storm_data (pd.DataFrame, optional) – The storm data to plot. Defaults to the class attribute storm_data.

  • variable (str) – The variable to plot. Defaults to ‘vmax’.

  • window (int) – The number of years to group for each time window. Defaults to 5.

  • show_plot (bool) – Whether to display the plot(s). Defaults to True.

  • plot_path (str) – Path to save the plot(s). If plotting multiple seasons, provide a directory path. Defaults to ‘’ (does not save).

Returns:

The matplotlib Axes object with the plot.

Return type:

Axes

Raises:

ValueError – If variable is not supported.

plot_fit(storm_data=None, variable='vmax', ev_params=None, show_plot=True, plot_path='')¶

Plots the fit of the data.

Parameters:

  • storm_data (pd.DataFrame, optional) – The storm data to plot. Defaults to the class attribute storm_data.

  • variable (str) – The variable to plot. Defaults to ‘vmax’.

  • ev_params –

    The GEV parameters to use for fitting.

    • If array-like, should be an array like of (shape, loc, scale).

    • If a dict, should be {season: (shape, loc, scale)}.

    Defaults to None, which uses the fitted parameters stored in the class attribute ev_params_.

  • show_plot (bool) – Whether to display the plot(s). Defaults to True.

  • plot_path (str) – Path to save the plot(s). If plotting multiple seasons, provide a directory path. Defaults to ‘’ (does not save).

Returns:

The matplotlib Axes object(s) with the plot(s).

Return type:

Axes or list[Axes]

Raises:

  • ValueError – If variable is not supported.

  • TypeError – If ev_params is not a tuple, list, or dict.

plot_time(storm_data=None, variable='vmax', ev_params=None, show_plot=True, plot_path='')¶

Plots the empirical mean and standard deviation and the parameters of the fitted GEV distribution over time.

Parameters:

  • storm_data (pd.DataFrame, optional) – The storm data to plot. Defaults to the class attribute storm_data.

  • variable (str) – The variable to plot. Defaults to ‘vmax’.

  • ev_params (dict) – The GEV parameters to use for fitting, should be {season: (shape, loc, scale)}. Defaults to None, which uses the fitted parameters stored in the class attribute ev_params_.

  • show_plot (bool) – Whether to display the plot(s). Defaults to True.

  • plot_path (str) – Path to save the plot(s). If plotting multiple seasons, provide a directory path. Defaults to ‘’ (does not save).

Raises:

  • ValueError – If variable is not supported.

  • TypeError – If ev_params is not a dictionary.

Return type:

Axes

score(storm_data=None, variable='vmax', ev_params=None)¶

Scores the fit of the data to the GEV distribution with the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test.

Parameters:

  • storm_data (pd.DataFrame, optional) – The storm data to score against. Defaults to the class attribute storm_data.

  • variable (str) – The variable to score. Defaults to ‘vmax’.

  • ev_params – The GEV parameters to use for scoring. - If array-like, should be an array like of (shape, loc, scale). - If a dict, should be {season: (shape, loc, scale)}.

Returns:

An object with the following attributes:

  • statistic (float): KS test statistic.

  • pvalue (float): One-tailed or two-tailed p-value.

  • statistic_location (float): The distance between the empirical distribution function and hypothesized cumulative distribution function is measured at this observation.

  • statistic_sign (int):

Return type:

KstestResult

Raises:

ValueError – If variable is not supported.
